title: Share your small wins! I need some positivity today

posts.body:
I've been reading some really heavy threads today. All valid, all important. But I could use some good news.

Can we share wins? Big or small. What's going right, even if it's just one thing?

I'll start: My mom has pretty advanced dementia. She usually doesn't know who I am. But today she looked at me while I was brushing her hair and said "Patricia, you're so good to me."

My name. She said my name. For the first time in months.

I sat in the car afterward and cried for twenty minutes. Happy tears, for once.

What's your win?

Pat, that made ME tear up. Those moments of clarity are gifts.

My win: After MONTHS of refusing, my dad finally agreed to let a home health aide help with showers. He was so resistant—said he wasn't going to let a stranger see him naked. I thought it would never happen.

The aide we found is a former Marine like him. First visit, they spent ten minutes talking about their service before even getting started. Dad actually laughed. He asked when "that guy" was coming back.

It's such a weight off. And proof that the right match makes all the difference.

I love this thread.

My win is small but it feels big: Yesterday I took a full hour for myself. Left my husband with his sister, drove to a coffee shop, and read my book. Alone. Didn't check my phone once.

A year ago I would have felt too guilty to do that. Yesterday I did it and I came back actually refreshed instead of empty.

The mental shift—accepting that I need breaks and deserve them—that's the real win.

My wife has MS. Walking has been really difficult lately—she's been using the wheelchair more than the walker.

This morning she walked from the bedroom to the kitchen. Just the walker. No wheelchair. No me hovering right beside her.

Halfway there she looked back at me and grinned. Like a kid who just learned to ride a bike.

It's not a cure. It might not last. Tomorrow might be harder. But today, right now, that walk happened. And I'm going to hold onto it.

This thread is exactly what I needed.

My win: After six months of tension, my brother and I finally had a real conversation about Mom's care. Not a fight—a conversation. He actually listened.

We came up with a plan. He's going to contribute more financially. I stay as primary caregiver. We check in monthly so nothing builds up.

We're not perfect. But we're functioning as a team again instead of adversaries. That feels like the biggest win of all.

Small win but I'm proud of it: I finally figured out the medication management app I downloaded three months ago and never actually used.

My mom takes 9 medications at 4 different times with different food requirements. I've been tracking it on paper and making mistakes.

Now I have alarms. Color-coded. With notes about which ones need food. I haven't missed a dose in two weeks.

Technology win. Took me way too long, but I got there.

Today's win: I took my dad to the botanical garden.

He's been depressed and difficult lately. Resistant to everything. But surrounded by flowers, something in him relaxed. He was like his old self for an hour. Cracking jokes. Noticing beauty. Holding my hand.

We don't get many perfect hours anymore. Today I got one.

I'm going to remember it on the hard days.

Every one of these made me smile. The Marine aide. The coffee shop hour. The bedroom-to-kitchen walk. The sibling peace treaty. The app victory. The perfect hour in the garden.

This is what gets us through—noticing the good moments, however brief.

I'm bookmarking this thread to re-read on the hard days. Thank you all for sharing.
